p: Docosapentaenoic acid (DPA; (7 Z,10 Z,13 Z,16 Z,19 Z)-docosa-7,10,13,16,19-pentaenoic acid), tradinionally called clupanodonic acid, shows structural similarity to EPA but has two more carbon atoms in the chain. Significant amounts are present in meat (13.8/16.7% of wether/ewe (lamb) raw meat FAs) [ 116], fish roe (5.5% of salmon roe total lipids [ 59], fish oils (1.04–2.82% of European wels catfish oil) [ 52], seal oil (2.64–4.74%) [ 62], and fish muscle (1.6% of wild sardine ( Sardina pilchardus) muscle total fatty acids) [ 61]. DPA sporadically occurs in algae such as Hormosira banksii and Dictyota dichomota (0.07% and 1.6% of total FAs, respectively) [ 117].
